Award.AwardTitle: Efficacy Study of Metropolitan Denver's Urban Advantage Program: A Project to Improve Scientific Literacy Among Urban Middle School Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an efficacy study through which the Denver Museum of Nature and Science, the Denver Zoo, the Denver Botanic Gardens, and three of Denver's urban school districts join efforts to determine if partnerships among formal and informal organizations demonstrate an appropriate infrastructure for improving science literacy among urban middle school science students. The Metropolitan Denver Urban Advantage (UA Denver) program is used for this purpose. This program consists of three design elements: (a) student-driven investigations, (b) STEM-related content, and (c) alignment of schools and informal science education institutions; and six major components: (a) professional development for teachers, (b) classroom materials and resources, (c) access to science-rich organizations, (d) outreach to families, (e) capacity building and sustainability, and (e) program assessment and student learning. Three research questions guide the study: (1) How does the participation in the program affect students' science knowledge, skills, and attitudes toward science relative to comparison groups of students? (2) How does the participation in the program affect teachers' science knowledge, skills, and abilities relative to comparison groups of teachers? and (3) How do families' participation in the program affect their engagement in and support for their children's science learning and aspirations relative to comparison families?

The study's guiding hypothesis is that the UA Denver program should improve science literacy in urban middle school students measured by (a) students' increased understanding of science, as reflected in their science investigations or "exit projects"; (b) teachers' increased understanding of science and their ability to support students in their exit projects, as documented by classroom observations, observations of professional development activities, and surveys; and (c) school groups' and families' increased visits to participating science-based institutions, through surveys. The study employs an experimental research design. Schools are randomly assigned to either intervention or comparison groups and classrooms will be the units of analysis. Power analysis recommended a sample of 18 intervention and 18 comparison middle schools, with approximately 72 seventh grade science teachers, over 5,000 students, and 12,000 individual parents in order to detect differences among intervention and comparison groups. To answer the three research questions, data gathering strategies include: (a) students' standardized test scores from the Colorado Student Assessment Program, (b) students' pre-post science learning assessment using the Northwest Evaluation Association's Measures for Academic Progress (science), (c) students' pre-post science aspirations and goals using the Modified Attitude Toward Science Inventory, (d) teachers' fidelity of implementation using the Teaching Science as Inquiry instrument, and (e) classroom interactions using the Science Teacher Inquiry Rubric, and the Reformed Teaching Observation protocol. To interpret the main three levels of data (students, nested in teachers, nested within schools), hierarchical linear modeling (HLM), including HLM6 application, are utilized. An advisory board, including experts in research methodologies, science, informal science education, assessment, and measurement oversees the progress of the study and provides guidance to the research team. An external evaluator assesses both formative and summative aspects of the evaluation component of the scope of work.

The key outcome of the study is a research-informed and field-tested intervention implemented under specific conditions for enhancing middle school science learning and teaching, and supported by partnerships between formal and informal organizations.

Institution.Name: Denver Museum of Nature and Science
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: COLORADO MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: Denver Museum of Nature and Science

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urban Advantage Metro Denver (UA), a partnership between urban public school districts and informal science education institutions (ISEIs), is designed to improve middle school students’ science literacy by improving teachers’ inquiry-based instruction and providing opportunities in and out of school for students to explore and investigate scientifically. The UA Denver program was implemented from September 2010 - August 2015. The program reached 35 unique schools, 86 unique teachers, and 14,439 students and their families.

Study Findings

To measure project outcomes, teachers, students, and families from participating UA and nonUA schools completed surveys in the fall and spring of the 2014-2015 academic year, while classrooms were observed in the winter. Standardized science test scores aggregated at the school level were also examined.

UA teachers engaged in more inquiry-based classroom practices. Classroom observations found that UA teachers spent a greater proportion of class time in student-directed investigation-related experiences (43%) than did nonUA teachers (19%). Additionally, UA teachers reported greater changes from fall to spring incorporating inquiry in their classrooms and their perceived competence in incorporating inquiry than nonUA teachers. Even UA students reported a greater frequency of inquiry-related activities in their classrooms than nonUA students.

UA teachers did not report feeling more competent engaging students in science than did nonUA teachers. UA Denver’s professional development focus was on inquiry and investigation-related experiences related to the Science and Engineering Practices from the Next Generation Science Standards rather than general science content. A more specific question may have helped to better understand this nuance and any impact therein.

UA teachers showed a moderate positive change from fall to spring in their attitude toward teaching science and the extent to which they believed their enthusiasm for science inspired enthusiasm in their students compared to nonUA teachers.

No differences were observed in Colorado standardized assessment science scores between UA and nonUA schools. Schools were classified as UA if one or more of their 7th grade science teachers had been a UA participant in the previous year. Scores for the 2013-2014 and 2014-2015 school years were similar between nonUA and UA schools, even after adjustment for school demographics. It may be that these analyses were not sensitive enough to detect differences, if they did exist, as some schools classified as UA included students who were not in a UA classroom.

UA students expressed greater likelihood of participating in science-related events and activities in the summer and following school year compared to nonUA students.

Among UA students, greater exposure to UA was correlated with positive outcomes. These outcomes included confidence in ability to perform science investigation-related activities, positive attitude toward science, and pride in the work done in their science class.

Greater exposure to UA was correlated with greater family support for their student pursuing science.

Teachers participating in UA had a more positive attitude toward ISEIs, seeing them as places where science is happening and as good resources for their students’ science learning, compared to nonUA teachers.

UA students and their families had greater engagement with the partner ISEIs. Compared to nonUA students, UA students reported a greater number of visits to the ISEIs in 7th grade, taking more field trips, and making visits with family or friends. Visits to the ISEIs were a major component of the UA program, and it was encouraging to see that UA students did report greater frequency of interactions with the ISEIs. UA families reported a greater number of visits to the partner ISEIs than did nonUA families. UA parents were more likely to agree that 7th grade science had a positive impact on their relationship with the partner ISEIs than nonUA parents.

Some outcomes examined did not show any significant differences between UA and nonUA populations nor change over the course of the year. UA teachers did not report a higher frequency of interaction with other teachers nor a greater sense that they were part of a learning community; UA students did not report a significantly higher perception of their ability to do various science investigation-related activities, attitude towards science, considering themselves a scientist, being proud of the work done in science class, completing a science project of which they were proud, and attitude toward the partner ISEIs; UA families did not report greater extents to which they engage in science-related activities, support their student in science, attitude toward partner ISEIs, and perception of impact of 7th grade science on family support for student in science.

Broader Impacts

This unique partnership between informal science institutions and urban school districts demonstrates a new infrastructure for supporting science teaching and learning. UA Denver‘s efforts to improve student science literacy is being achieved by tapping into the resources and expertise of the informal science institutions while simultaneously leveraging the school districts’ support systems for curricular integration and student success.


Last Modified: 11/01/2016
Modified by: Nancy E Walsh

The UA Denver program was implemented from September 2010 - August 2015. The program reached 35 unique schools, 86 unique teachers, and 14,439 students and their families. Even UA students reported a greater frequency of inquiry-related activities in their classrooms than nonUA students. A more specific question may have helped to better understand this nuance and any impact therein.
